text.tspan: Help! Should I include an anecdote?
I have an important paper due in two days, and I am struggling to decide
whether I should include an anecdote in my writing. I have heard conflicting
opinions on the form of evidence, and am wondering what the writing
studies community has to say about it. Will it persuasively support my
message, or will it distract readers from listening to what I have to say?
Thanks in Advance!
~ AspiringWriter75
Replies (12):
@Aristotle
@AspiringWriter75
My study of rhetoric has led me to believe that anecdotes can be a useful tool in
addressing large crowds and in quickly demonstrating the merits of an idea. For
example, the great storyteller Aesop told fables that could convince huge audiences of
his perspective. That being said, it would be better if you used evidence based on
historical facts instead of telling a story. The past is the greatest predictor of the future,
so anecdotes are little more than a suboptimal substitute for fact-based evidence.
@John Reinard
@Aristotle @AspiringWriter75
Modern data disagrees with your classical beliefs that anecdotes are merely a weaker
version of empirical evidence. Analysis of studies from the 1950’s shows that statistics
and anecdotes do not differ significantly in their ability to persuade an audience. And,
contemporary research suggests that anecdotal reporting is more powerful than
numerical data as anecdotes often get closer to the subject being discussed than lone
numbers.
@James Baesler
@John @Aristotle
This conversation relates to my research which breaks evidence down into two
categories: testimonial and fact. Testimonial evidence is anything that does not
have a mathematical basis. It instead tells a story that supports the writer’s
perspective. On the other side of things, factual evidence uses statistical and
observational evidence to support a writer’s argument. Analyzing more recent
studies has led me to conclude that there is mixed evidence as to which form of
evidence is more generally persuasive, so that I must also disagree with
Aristotle's claim that anecdotes are strictly worse than fact-based alternatives.
